title: Shane Webcke
text:
Shane Webcke (born 28 September 1974) is an Australian former professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer, who spent his entire club career playing for the <a href="Brisbane%20Broncos">Brisbane Broncos</a>. Webcke represented <a href="Queensland%20Maroons">Queensland</a> in the <a href="Rugby%20League%20State%20of%20Origin">State of Origin</a> 21 times and also captained the side. He made 26 test appearances for <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australia</a>. His position was <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Prop%20forwards">prop forward</a> and at his peak he was renowned as the best front rower in the world. Alongside <a href="Glenn%20Lazarus">Glenn Lazarus</a> and <a href="Arthur%20Beetson">Arthur Beetson</a>, Webcke is considered by many to have been one of the finest post-war front-rowers to play the game.
After retiring in 2006, Webcke became the Sunday–Thursday sports presenter on "<a href="Seven%20News%23Brisbane">Seven News</a>" in his hometown of Brisbane, a position he holds to this day.
Early life.
Webcke was born in <a href="Toowoomba">Toowoomba</a>, <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, of German and Scottish descent. 
Originally from <a href="Leyburn%2C%20Queensland">Leyburn, Queensland</a> and having played for Toowoomba, Webcke was scouted by <a href="Wayne%20Bennett%20%28rugby%20league%29">Wayne Bennett</a>, whom he acknowledges as the greatest influence on his career, after seeing him play as a schoolboy in 1993. The following year Webcke's father was killed in a work accident when he was still 19 years of age.
Playing career.
1990s.
Webcke made his debut for the Broncos in the <a href="1995%20ARL%20season">1995 ARL season</a>. Within two seasons he had his first premiership ring, when he helped Brisbane to victory over the <a href="Cronulla-Sutherland%20Sharks">Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks</a> in the <a href="1997%20Super%20League%20%28Australia%29%20season">1997 Super League season</a>'s grand final.
Webcke made his first appearance for the <a href="Queensland%20Maroons">Queensland Maroons</a> in the first game of the <a href="1998%20State%20of%20Origin%20series">1998 State of Origin series</a> and was named man of the match in the third and deciding game that year. From his debut until his retirement from representative football following Game III in 2004, no other player wore the number 8 for Queensland.
Webcke won his second grand final in <a href="1998%20NRL%20grand%20final">1998</a>, when the Broncos defeated the <a href="Canterbury%20Bulldogs">Canterbury Bulldogs</a>.
2000s.
In 2000 Webcke broke his arm during the finals series that season but went on to play for the Broncos in their <a href="2000%20NRL%20grand%20final">grand final victory</a> over the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a>. Post-season he was a member of the Australian team that won the <a href="2000%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2000 Rugby League World Cup</a>. Webcke was also awarded the <a href="Australian%20Sports%20Medal">Australian Sports Medal</a> for his contribution to Australia's international standing in rugby league. Following Australia's World Cup victory, Webcke and teammate <a href="Gorden%20Tallis">Gorden Tallis</a> wrote an open letter to players appealing for an end to scandalous behaviour amongst footballers which had been tarnishing the sport.
Having won the 2000 NRL Premiership, the Broncos travelled to England to play against 2000's <a href="Super%20League%20V">Super League V</a> Champions, <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> for the <a href="2001%20World%20Club%20Challenge">2001 World Club Challenge</a>, with Webcke playing at prop forward in Brisbane's loss.
Webcke won the Broncos' best player award for the <a href="2001%20Brisbane%20Broncos%20season">2001 season</a>. Post-season he refused to tour with the Kangaroos in the wake of the <a href="11%20September%20attacks">11 September attacks</a>. At the end of the <a href="2003%20NRL%20season">2003 NRL season</a>, he went on the <a href="2003%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">2003 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain and France</a>, helping Australia to victory over <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> the last time rugby league's <a href="Ashes%20series">Ashes series</a> was contested. Webcke was selected in the Australian team to compete in the <a href="2004%20Rugby%20League%20Tri-Nations">2004 Tri-Nations</a> tournament. In the final against Great Britain he played in the Kangaroos' 44–4 victory. With the representative retirement of <a href="Gorden%20Tallis">Gorden Tallis</a> and an injury to <a href="Darren%20Lockyer">Darren Lockyer</a>, Webcke captained <a href="Queensland%20State%20of%20Origin%20team">Queensland</a> in <a href="2004%20State%20of%20Origin%20series%23Game%20I">Game 1 of the 2004 State of Origin series</a>, which the Maroons lost 9–8 in golden point extra time. Webcke again won the Paul Morgan Medal for the Broncos' best and fairest player for the <a href="2005%20Brisbane%20Broncos%20season">2005 season</a>.
Webcke announced on 26 April 2006 that he would retire at the end of the <a href="2006%20NRL%20season">2006 NRL season</a>. Webcke's final game was the Broncos' victory in the <a href="2006%20NRL%20Grand%20Final">2006 grand final</a> against the <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a>, days after his 32nd birthday.
Post-playing.
Post-football, Webcke went on to release his auto-biography, "Warhorse" and also ventured into media with the <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> in his hometown of Brisbane, presenting sport on the local "<a href="Seven%20News%23Brisbane">Seven News</a>" bulletin on Sundays to Thursdays. He also worked on-screen with <a href="Matthew%20Johns">Matthew Johns</a> in the first and only season of "<a href="The%20Matty%20Johns%20Show">The Matty Johns Show</a>".
Webcke's <a href="pub">pub</a> at <a href="Leyburn%2C%20Queensland">Leyburn, Queensland</a> – the Royal Hotel – is the longest, continuously licensed premises in Queensland.
Webcke was set to become the first player to give the annual <a href="Tom%20Brock%20Lecture">Tom Brock Lecture</a> when he was invited to do so in 2007, but this did not eventuate.
In 2007 at the Broncos' 20-year anniversary celebration, the club announced a list of the 20 best players to play for them to date which included Webcke.
In February 2008, Webcke was named in the list of Australia's <a href="List%20of%20Australian%20rugby%20league%27s%20100%20greatest%20players">"100 Greatest Players"</a> (1908–2007) which was commissioned by the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> and <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">ARL</a> to celebrate the code's centenary year in Australia.
A few months later the Brisbane Broncos appointed Shane Webcke, along with <a href="Allan%20Langer">Allan Langer</a>, as full-time assistant coaches to work alongside new head coach <a href="Ivan%20Henjak">Ivan Henjak</a> from the <a href="Brisbane%20Broncos%202009">2009 season</a>. However, shortly after the start of the season, Webcke quit his post in the wake of controversy surrounding the release of his new book in which he was openly critical of the Broncos administration not standing down star players <a href="Darius%20Boyd">Darius Boyd</a>, <a href="Sam%20Thaiday">Sam Thaiday</a> and <a href="Karmichael%20Hunt">Karmichael Hunt</a> when police were investigating sexual assault allegations against them in September 2008. He went on to state that he was 'filthy' about the state of affairs at the Broncos.
Accolades.
Dally M Prop Of The Year: 2000, 2001, 2002
<a href="Ron%20McAuliffe%20Medal">Ron McAuliffe Medal</a>: 2002
Rugby League Week Player of the Year: 2001
Named in NRL Team of the 1990s: 2003
